factoid: The adjutant said that a thing flew a hair’s breadth past his ear.
The peasants adjusted the stretcher to their shoulders.
The peasants started hurriedly along the path they had trodden down.
The peasants went to the dressing station.
An officer shouted "Keep in step! Ah... those peasants!".
An officer seized the peasants by their shoulders.
An officer checked the peasants.
The peasants were walking unevenly.
The peasants were jolting the stretcher.
The foremost peasant said "Get into step, Fëdor... I say, Fëdor!".
The peasant behind said "Now that’s right!" when he had got into step.
Timókhin, who had run up and was looking down on the stretcher, said "Your excellency! Eh, Prince!".
Prince Andrew opened his eyes.
Prince Andrew looked up at the speaker from the stretcher into which his head had sunk deep.
Prince Andrew's eyelids drooped again.
The militiamen carried Prince Andrew to the dressing station by the wood.
Wagons were stationed at the dressing station by the wood.
The dressing station consisted of three tents with flaps turned back, pitched at the edge of a birch wood.
Wagons were standing in the wood.
Horses were standing in the wood.
The horses were eating oats from their movable troughs.
Sparrows flew down and pecked the grains that fell.
Some crows flew among the birch trees cawing impatiently.
Bloodstained men in various garbs stood around the tents.
Bloodstained men in various garbs sat around the tents.
Bloodstained men in various garbs lay around the tents.
Crowds of soldier stretcher-bearers with dismal and attentive faces stood around the wounded.
Officers keeping order tried in vain to drive the soldier stretcher-bearers from the spot.
The soldiers stood leaning against their stretchers.
The soldiers gazed intently.
The soldiers were trying to comprehend the difficult problem of what was taking place before them.
Loud angry cries came from the tents.
Plaintive groans came from the tents.
Dressers ran out to fetch water occasionally.
Dressers ran out to point out those who were to be brought in next occasionally.
The wounded men awaiting their turn outside the tents groaned.
The wounded men awaiting their turn outside the tents sighed.
The wounded men awaiting their turn outside the tents wept.
The wounded men awaiting their turn outside the tents screamed.
The wounded men awaiting their turn outside the tents swore.
The wounded men awaiting their turn outside the tents asked for vodka.
Some wounded men were delirious.
Prince Andrew’s bearers stepped over the wounded who had not yet been bandaged.
Prince Andrew’s bearers took Prince Andrew close up to one of the tents.
Prince Andrew’s bearers stopped there awaiting instructions.
Prince Andrew could not make out what was going on around him for a long time.
Prince Andrew remembered the meadow.
Prince Andrew remembered the wormwood.
Prince Andrew remembered the field.
Prince Andrew remembered the whirling black ball.
Prince Andrew remembered his sudden rush of passionate love of life.
A tall, handsome, black-haired noncommissioned officer with a bandaged head stood two steps from Prince Andrew.
The noncommissioned officer leaned against a branch.
The noncommissioned officer was talking loudly.
The noncommissioned officer was attracting general attention.
The noncommissioned officer had been wounded in the head and leg by bullets.
A crowd of wounded and stretcher-bearers was gathered around the noncommissioned officer.
The crowd of wounded and stretcher-bearers were eagerly listening to the noncommissioned officer's talk.
The noncommissioned officer said "We kicked him out from there so that he chucked everything, we grabbed the King himself!".
The noncommissioned officer looked around with eyes that glittered with fever.
The noncommissioned officer said "If only reserves had come up just then, lads, there wouldn’t have been nothing left of him! I tell you surely....".
Prince Andrew looked at the noncommissioned officer with shining eyes.
Prince Andrew experienced a sense of comfort.
Prince Andrew thought "But isn’t it all the same now?".
Prince Andrew thought "And what will be there, and what has there been here?".
Prince Andrew thought "Why was I so reluctant to part with life?".
Prince Andrew thought "There was something in this life I did not and do not understand.".
One of the doctors came out of the tent in a bloodstained apron.
One of the doctors was holding a cigar between the thumb and little finger of one of his small bloodstained hands.
The doctor raised his head.
The doctor looked around the area.
The doctor looked above the level of the wounded men.
The doctor wanted a little respite.
The doctor turned his head from right to left for some time.
The doctor sighed.
The doctor looked down.
The doctor replied "All right, immediately" to a dresser who pointed Prince Andrew out to the doctor.
The doctor told them to carry Prince Andrew into the tent.
Murmurs arose among the wounded who were waiting.
One wounded man remarked "It seems that even in the next world only the gentry are to have a chance!".
